comments:
Hi,
Generate Javadoc fails to run, although there are no errors or warnings in the code/comments and calling the Sun Javadoc directly from a programme runs correctly.

The same thing happens on every project in every workspace I have tried.

This is what I did:
I set up a new clean workspace, a simple Java project, with a few simple classes.
Nothing refers to anything external.
I can run com.sun.tools.javadoc.Main.execute(javadocargs) on this without any errors or warnings and nice Javadoc is created correctly.

If I try "Generate Javadoc" on the project with what appear to be the same settings, it throws an IllegalArgumentException (see below).

The only settings I have changed from the defaults are the reference to javadoc.exe and the location for the output.

I am using Sun J2SE 1.5.0_04.

A similar message comes for the first java file of any project I try it on.

The full exception message is:

After you used the Javadoc wizard, can you switch to the debug view and open the properties on it? You will see that the wizard creates a file with all options in a temp file. I would need the temp file to see why the Javadoc toool failes

It looks like an bug in the Javadoc tool however

Dear Martin,
I tried to catch the elusive temp file, but no luck.

There is a reference in Debug properties to a file:
...@C:\DOCUME~1\ROGERN~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\javadoc-arguments29106.tmp
Presumably, this is what you mean.

However, there is no such file visible in Windows Explorer at this location, nor in the Recycle Bin.

Perhaps something fails before it gets created, or do I need some different settings?

Best regards
Roger
The file will be removed after its use. You have to try to open it while it is there...

Created an attachment (id=30701)
Javadoc properties file

That was a challenge!  The file got away each time it appeared.

The attachment was produced by creating a different workspace and piling as many projects as I could think of into it, just to keep the Javadoc busy for long enough.  Still it threw the IllegalArgumentException at the end, so I guess it is valid.

Best regards
Roger

The command line looks good. I don't think we do anything wrong there.
The bug seems to be in the Javadoc command. Can you try another JRE? Is maybe the JRE you used for Eclipse a different JRE?

What happens if you call the Javadoc tool on the command line (you could use the file that you rescued)
-> javadoc.exe @file

Setting to INVALID as I think the bug must be in the Javadoc command. Reopen the bug if you disagree.

Gueti Idee!

It is indeed a bug in Javadoc (Bug ID 6219854) and in my classpath.
I pruned the classpath to the minimum necessary and now it works.

Thanks
Roger
